desc: STAT3 (Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3) encodes a transcription factor that is regulated by cytokines and growth factors including Interferons (IFNs), Epidermal growth factor (EGF), Interleukin 5 and 6 (IL5, IL6), Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF), and Bone morphogenetic protein 2 (BMP2) (PMID: 26464811). STAT3 is phosphorylated by Janus kinase (JAK) kinases, resulting in dimerization and nuclear translocation (PMID: 25527793). STAT3 is involved in regulating development of the skin, central nervous system, and mammary tissue (PMID:11994402, 10342556). Activated STAT3 is found in various cancer types, most notably in breast cancer, and implicated in pathways important for survival, immune dysregulation, tumor microenvironment modulation and cellular invasion (PMID: 25342631, 11420660, 21310826, 16463269). Activation of STAT3 may also be a means of tumor drug resistance (PMID: 25065853). STAT3 mutations are found in hyper-IgE syndrome characterized by elevated IgE levels, connective tissue abnormalities, and immunodeficiency (PMID: 17881745). Germline mutations in STAT3 are also associated with autoimmunity and lymphoproliferation (PMID: 25359994). In cancer, activating STAT3 mutations are found in large granular lymphocytic leukemia and more rarely in myelodysplastic syndrome, aplastic anemia, and lymphomas (PMID: 22591296, 23926297, 25586472). Mutations have also been found in inflammatory hepatocellular adenomas, and copy number alterations have been identified in breast cancer samples (PMID: 21690253, 25470049).

desc: STAT3 encodes a transcription factor involved in the pro-oncogenic JAK signaling cascade. Germline mutations of STAT3 are associated with autoimmunity and lymphoproliferation and predispose to hematologic cancers.

gene.name: signal transducer and activator of transcription 3
